text: <@U33EGB4TX>  I did not find the restriction you placed on yourself in the guild wheel series interesting. The end product lists were not something I would consider running even on my lower powered nights. You write very well and your fine at list building so I feel removing restrictions like that may provide creative lists that are something I would be interested in experimenting with.

Thanks for the feedback. The project wasn't for everyone, it was just an exercise in deck building. Not all of the articles are going to appeal to everyone. I just wanted to show that you can build unique decks without having the same sol ring/cultivate/staple cards in all of them. I feel like I accomplished my goals alright, sorry if it didn't interest you too much.
we think a “news” article is warranted for this edhrec is ruining edh thing?
i think i dont want to get involved
just bringing it up since it did get a decent amount of attention
IMO don't give them attention for their shitty attention-getting antics
:thumbsup:
Yeah...I'd let that just die off.
Yea, I don't think this is the type of attention we really want to latch on to. I can get a news update written if you want though

Had the rebuttal piece on Monday been an actual rebuttal I might question their sincerity less, but given how dashed-off that piece was it feels pretty clear that they primarily cared about the clickbait Friday headline.
Yeah
Do you want me to do a "here's something that people talked about us on. Here's the Reddit thread for more conversation" article <@U286Q175Y>? Or leave it be?
Dont do it
Deal
Let this dog die...
In the aaaaaaaarrrms oooof the angelllllllllsss
About net decking gate, this comment was in the reddit thread :

"EDHrec is ruining EDH" is the stupidest nontroversy in recent MTG memory, and we collectively gave a garbage article more attention that it deserved. A cynical person like me might even consider that the entire thing was intentionally manufactured by the website to generate clicks (both angry at the obvious flame bait, and then double again at the "good" reply). But that would be a cynical bastard of a person, so let's give them the benefit of the doubt and not attribute malice where ignorance fits equally well.

So if we must: 

1. And honestly the argument should just die here Don't use it if you don't like. Nobody forces you to use the website. If you copy edhrec for every deck you make then the problem is not the website, it's you. You're uncreative and/or ignorant and not using the website will just make your decks even more garbage as well as unoriginal. If you use the website but "wish it didn't exist" you're genuinely fucking retarded "jamesd". 

2. The website doesn't force you to pick any cards, nor does it even give you a "proper" decklist... Frankensteining a deck together exclusively by mashing the top recommended from edhrec is usually a terrible idea. Do people even read? It's literally just telling you cards people who submit decklists on the internet use commonly with that commander. This is especially true for Atraxa actually, which leads us to the next point:

3. ~Jamesd is a fucking imbecile~ Typo. I mean, Atraxa has at least 3 viable "common" builds (yes, there are many more, no you're not a deckbuilding genius, hint: Atraxa PRAETOR'S VOICE goes well with negative counters and infect, Phyrexian mechanics) - stax, superfriends, +1/+1 creatures. James "Bloody Stupid" d says everyone builds Atraxa superfriends because of edhrec... Let's look at edhrec's top recommended cards! Oh wait, there are 2 Planeswalkers in 10 Top Cards + 14 Signature cards, and they're not even exclusive to superfriends. Welp. In fact if you just collate the top recommended from Atraxa's page you get an hybrid, but mostly creature based, +1/+1 creature deck... which, because that's how aggregate sites and mathematics work you idiot, means that statistically that's the most common build. So when you say "everyone" you really mean "your friends", which is a problem with your friends not with edhrec. 

4. The entire article is a pile of stupid, "facts pulled out of my ass", opinions, like "Nobody's having fun in standard". James, while you were eating lead-based paint chips as a kid, did you ever wonder why anyone does anything they're not forced to? Because they're having fun. Even if it has negatives. Even if they say otherwise or bitch about it, like certain wastes of genetic dna complaining about websites they keep using. If you're not actually forced to do something the reason you do it is because you get something positive out of it. People play games for fun. Even when they get angry, if they keep playing it, it's because it's fun. When you say "nobody's having fun [with standard]" you're also pulling this statistic out of the deepest crevices of your bowls. I have fun with standard, so, objectively, there goes "nobody". I know a lot of other people that have fun with standard. I've seen pro players comment on how Amonkhet made standard more interesting, and so forth. 

I could go on tearing apart the shit smear people reflexively insist on referring to as "an article", but why? Why even give it the attention? There are now 2 top threads on this forum talking about this worthless garbage already, any of them (including the one that's just a title) have more thought put into it than the original verbal diarrhea.

In short, the original article is a pile of stupid. Don't give it anymore attention than you would a five year old flailing around for attention.
And this was the response of the site's account :

1) For the record - we don't advertise at all on the site. Never have.
2) Also for the record -we're a grassroots blog written by a bunch of friends, and published on a pretty loose schedule. Clicks be damned.
3) Thanks for reading. 4) Related - The purpose of these two point/counterpoint articles is exactly this - to get people reading and talking about the different angles as they apply to the format. This format that we all love deserves our attention, and that's also why we write. We love talking about it too, and we love it when people engage us and others about it. If that happens, regardless of your opinion, we've done our job.
5) On a personal note, I'm glad you have a visceral reaction here. I'm glad for everyone who does - it means you're passionate about EDH, and that's why we're all here. 

But - not to be pedantic or anything - even on Reddit, your argument loses a ton of steam when you resort to childish name-calling. I'd love to dig in to the meat of what you're saying here, but I see works like "imbecile" and "retarded", and I immediately tune both you and your opinion out. 

I mean - an op-ed about a game, and you're calling the author retarded? Really? 

Show some basic respect. Then, we can get back to the discussion.
I'm not sure they were after click bait. I think they're just some really casual dudes
Having written for another blog like theirs  apparently, I would have gladly done a few clickbait entries for clicks
Hell. We tried writing about Pokémon which I have no clue under the sun about. But it was hip and we got lots of views.
I love how when u give constructive criticism that dean gives me a thumbs down. Makes this feel like an open environment where I can give honest feedback. >_>
Yeah the comment I thumbs down'd came off, to me, as negative, and like you didn't understand what the point of the series was on a deeper than surface level
It stands to reason then not everyone might not understand then the deeper meaning you're referring to.

I try very hard to keep my comments on others articles positive. I like his writing style a lot and enjoy reading his update articles for that reason, just was bummed out that the restriction for me made the outcome of the article something I knew I personally wouldn't be in to.

I'd also argue that restrictions build way more creativity than none. I can't recall if it was an interview or article, but Chris Miller and Phil Lord made some great comments once about how having to work within the confines of something like a Lego movie or a movie version of 21 Jump Street forces creative solutions in a way a blank canvass never could.
Making a great Lego movie feels way more impressive to me than just making a great kids movie.

<@U3SV1JGP7> I think you hit the nail on the head there. The articles are just something you wouldn't be in to. Which is fine. Like I said, I didn't write the series for everyone, just like you don't write for everyone. It's just a difference in opinion and that's fine. I'm glad you enjoy my style and maybe in the future you'll like some other stuff more
Yeah, I thought you were looking for feedback and was trying my best to phrase it in a way that might help.
It'd be nice when I'm trying to give feedback not to have others not to be rude about it.
And i honestly don't know who I write for.
Mobile... Typos
Like the comments I see in mine are all over the place. Shrugs.
I think my goal has just been to contribute in some way back to the edh community.
And maybe that just takes time to find out who your articles appeal to the most. It definitely took some time for a few readers to grasp the series I did.

I wish to address a larger issue in this exchange. This forum is an open place where everyone can express their opinion and thoughts. However, communication is a two-way street vs a 1-lane country road where you have the right of way. If you express an opinion others are free to agree or disagree with it, so long as they are civil. You should not interpret their disagreement as an attempt to stifle your opinion.
Disagreement and discourse is fine. I find a thumbs down emoji inappropriate and rude.
A simple statement of (I think you might not be interested in it as I feel you are only seeing the surface part of the articles objective) would have been a fine and appropriate response.
That's the difference.
Fair enough
On a scale from 1-"the content restriction you placed on yourself for your series wasn't interesting" how rude was it?
That's not what I wrote
Maybe not verbatim, but the message might be closer to that than you intended it to
Not being able to pick up on everyone's tone and no verbal communication certainly doesn't help the forum like Henry said
I agree
Maybe it would best to apply a glass half full attitude to my statements in the future and I'll work on adding additional clarity to them.

So maybe instead of putting all the work on everyone else to sift through, knowing we can't pick up on some intent through just text, maybe finding a way to soften what you say keeping in mind that we all have to might be the best route?
I know I have had to work quite a bit on that personally.
I thought that was soft XD. I can work on it tho.
I think it just came across as dismissive a bit, which is what Dean was trying to say. Knowing the past conversations we've all had I kind of picked up on what the intent was, but it wasn't easy.
If several people are telling me something that I don't see, when does it become me being the one that can't see the issue and it not being there?
If you'd rather go to DM's too that works for me. That way we aren't spamming everyone
This is probs no longer article relevant
Yep. Thus my offer to keep the conversation going in private

<@U33EGB4TX> I liked the idea of the restriction. I do think the restriction was on the easy side. With 16,000 cards to choose from the limit wasn't constrictive enough, in my opinion. It also took readers longer to fully grasp the restriction, since the first few articles there would not much crossover anyways. That being said I love the idea. If the restriction was tweaked to be a certain number of blocks, formats, or solely one set of colors I could see it becoming very popular. Even taking the card pool you've used and keep building from that. With more decks pulling from that pool, it will create a diverse set of decks over a longer period of time.
Why not have the restriction instead be natural from a deck path or idea. Like for example. Dimir is the guild for Mill with szadek at the helm.
Just a thought.
Maybe I'm just bad at grasping the goal here.
Part 10 of the 10 part series was published Monday
While writing my article today, it dawned on me: why on earth did I not name my article series Dollar General?
Trademark infringement.
I am stealing that
I feel like that guy who comes up with the perfect come back... the next morning
Dollar General
